``` ### JavaScript Code for Mobile-Friendly Navigation To make the navigation menu mobile-friendly, you can add the following JavaScript code to toggle the navigation menu: ```javascript // Get the navigation menu and toggle button const navMenu = document.querySelector('nav ul'); const toggleButton = document.querySelector('nav button'); // Add event listener to toggle button toggleButton.addEventListener('click', () => { // Toggle the navigation menu navMenu.classList.toggle('hidden'); }); ``` ### CSS Code for Mobile-Friendly Navigation To hide the navigation menu on smaller screens, you can add the following CSS code: ```css /* Hide the navigation menu on smaller screens */ nav ul { display: flex; flex-direction: column; align-items: center; padding: 0; margin: 0; list-style: none; } /* Hide the navigation menu on smaller screens */ nav ul.hidden { display: none; } /* Show the navigation menu on larger screens */ @media (min-width: 768px) { nav ul { flex-direction: row; justify-content: space-between; } nav ul.hidden { display: flex; } } ``` Note that this is just an example of how you can improve the design and make it more accessible and mobile-friendly. You can customize the code to fit your specific needs and requirements.

These changes improve the accessibility, readability, and overall user experience of the SaaS landing page.
